common.auto_restart_interval: The auto restart interval after the resource is disconnected.
common.batch_size: Maximum batch count. If equal to 1, there's effectively no batching.
common.batch_time: Maximum waiting interval when accumulating a batch at a low message rates for more efficient resource usage.
common.enable_queue:
Enable disk buffer queue (only applicable for egress bridges).
When Enabled, messages will be buffered on disk when the bridge connection is down.
When disabled the messages are buffered in RAM only.
common.inflight_window: Query inflight window. When query_mode is set to async, this config has to be set to 1 if messages from the same MQTT client have to be strictly ordered.
common.request_ttl: Starting from the moment when the request enters the buffer, if the request remains in the buffer for the specified time or is sent but does not receive a response or acknowledgement in time, the request is considered expired.
common.start_timeout: Time interval to wait for an auto-started resource to become healthy before responding resource creation requests.
common.worker_pool_size:
The number of buffer workers. Only applicable for egress type bridges.
For bridges only have ingress direction data flow, it can be set to 0 otherwise must be greater than 0.
common.max_buffer_bytes: Maximum number of bytes to buffer for each buffer worker.
common.password: Password used for authentication with the external database.
common.pool_size: Size of the connection pool towards the bridge target service.
common.prepare_statement: Key-value list of SQL prepared statements.
common.username: The username in the external database used for authentication or identification purposes.
common.tcp_keepalive:
Enable TCP keepalive for connector.
The value is a comma-separated list of three numbers in the format of `Idle,Interval,Probes`
- Idle: The number of seconds of idle time needed by a connection before the server begins to send out keep-alive probes (default on Linux is 7200).
- Interval: The number of seconds between TCP keep-alive probes (default on Linux is 75).
- Probes: The maximum number of TCP keep-alive probes to send before considering the connection as closed if no response is received from the other end (default on Linux is 9).
For example "240,30,5" means: send TCP keepalive probes after 240 seconds of idle time, and send probes every 30 second. If there are no responses for 5 consecutive attempts, the connection should be closed.
Default: 'none'
common.sndbuf: Fine tune the socket send buffer. The default value is tuned for high throughput.
common.recbuf: Fine tune the socket receive buffer. The default value is tuned for high throughput.
common.nodelay: When set to `true`, TCP buffer is sent as soon as possible. Otherwise, the OS kernel may buffer small TCP packets for a while (40 ms by default).
common.pool_type: The type of the pool. Can be one of `random`, `hash`.
common.max_retries: Max retry times if an error occurs when sending a request.

mqtt.bridge_mode: This setting is only for MQTT protocol version older than 5.0, and the remote MQTT broker MUST support this feature. After being enabled, the remote broker will recognize the current connection as a bridge, that loop detection will be more effective and that retained messages will be propagated correctly.
mqtt.clean_start: Whether to start a clean session when reconnecting a remote broker for ingress bridge.
mqtt.retry_interval: Retry interval for QoS1/QoS2 messages if no ACK is received.
mqtt.clientid_prefix: The prefix used when the connector randomly generates a Client ID.
mqtt.max_inflight: The number of Unacked messages that can be simultaneously waited for during message publishing, in order to improve message delivery efficiency and throughput.
mqtt.topic: Message publishing topic, supports using ${'{'}field{'}'} syntax to extract variables and dynamically concatenate the topic.
mqtt.source_topic: Message subscription topics support the use of + and # wildcards. When EMQX is running in cluster mode or the connector is configured with a connection pool, shared subscriptions must be used to avoid message duplication.
mqtt.payload: For example: ${'{'}payload{'}'}, ${'{'}clientid{'}'}, ${'{'}topic{'}'} , ${'{'}username{'}'}, etc. Use fields according to the action requirements of your business and forwards the message as it is if it is empty.Supports reading data using ${'{'}field{'}'} syntax.

http.url:
The URL of the HTTP Connector.
Template with variables is allowed in the path, but variables cannot be used in the host or port part.
For example, `http://localhost:9901/${'{'}topic{'}'}` is allowed, but`http://${'{'}host{'}'}:9901/message` or `http://localhost:${'{'}port{'}'}/message`is not allowed.
http.body: For example: ${'{'}payload{'}'}, ${'{'}clientid{'}'}, ${'{'}topic{'}'} , ${'{'}username{'}'}, etc. Use fields according to the action requirements of your business and forwards the message as it is if it is empty.
http.path:
The URL path for this Action.
This path will be appended to the Connector's url configuration to form the full URL address.Template with variables is allowed in this option. For example, /room/{'{'}$room_no{'}'}

cassandra.servers:
The IPv4 or IPv6 address or the hostname to connect to.
A host entry has the following form: `Host[:Port][,Host2:Port]`.
The Cassandra default port 9042 is used if `[:Port]` is not specified.

clickhouse.batch_value_separator: The default value ',' works for the VALUES format. You can also use other separator if other format is specified. See [INSERT INTO Statement](https://clickhouse.com/docs/en/sql-reference/statements/insert-into).
clickhouse.connect_timeout: The timeout when connecting to the Clickhouse server.
clickhouse.url: The HTTP URL to the Clickhouse server that you want to connect to (for example http://myhostname:8123)
clickhouse.sql: The template string can contain ${'{'}field{'}'} placeholders for message metadata and payload field. Make sure that the inserted values are formatted and escaped correctly. [Prepared Statement](https://docs.emqx.com/en/enterprise/v5.0/data-integration/data-bridges.html#Prepared-Statement) is not supported.

dynamo.template:
Template, the default value is empty. When this value is empty the whole message will be stored in the database.
The template can be any valid json with placeholders and make sure all keys for table are here, example:
`{'{'}"id" : "${'{'}id{'}'}", "clientid" : "${'{'}clientid{'}'}", "data" : "${'{'}payload.data{'}'}"{'}'}`
dynamo.aws_access_key_id: Access Key ID for connecting to DynamoDB.
dynamo.aws_secret_access_key: AWS Secret Access Key for connecting to DynamoDB.

gcp_pubsub_producer.pipelining: A positive integer. Whether to send HTTP requests continuously, when set to 1, it means that after each HTTP request is sent, you need to wait for the server to return and then continue to send the next request.
gcp_pubsub_producer.connect_timeout: The timeout when connecting to the HTTP server.
gcp_pubsub_producer.service_account_json:
JSON containing the GCP Service Account credentials to be used with PubSub.
When a GCP Service Account is created (as described in https://developers.google.com/identity/protocols/oauth2/service-account#creatinganaccount), you have the option of downloading the credentials in JSON form. That's the file needed.
gcp_pubsub_producer.pubsub_topic: The GCP PubSub topic to publish messages to.
gcp_pubsub_producer.payload_template: The template for formatting the outgoing messages.  If undefined, will send all the available context in JSON format.
gcp_pubsub_producer.attributes_template: The template for formatting the outgoing message attributes.  Undefined values will be rendered as empty string values.  Empty keys are removed from the attribute map.
gcp_pubsub_producer.ordering_key_template: The template for formatting the outgoing message ordering key.  Undefined values will be rendered as empty string values.  This value will not be added to the message if it's empty.

gcp_pubsub_consumer.consumer_pubsub_topic: GCP PubSub topic to consume from.
gcp_pubsub_consumer.consumer_mqtt_topic: Local topic to which consumed GCP PubSub messages should be published to.
gcp_pubsub_consumer.consumer_qos: MQTT QoS used to publish messages consumed from GCP PubSub.
gcp_pubsub_consumer.payload_template: The template for formatting the outgoing messages.  If undefined, will send all the available context in JSON format.
gcp_pubsub_consumer.pipelining: A positive integer. Whether to send HTTP requests continuously, when set to 1, it means that after each HTTP request is sent, you need to wait for the server to return and then continue to send the next request.
gcp_pubsub_consumer.service_account_json:
JSON containing the GCP Service Account credentials to be used with PubSub.
When a GCP Service Account is created (as described in https://developers.google.com/identity/protocols/oauth2/service-account#creatinganaccount), you have the option of downloading the credentials in JSON form. That's the file needed.
gcp_pubsub_consumer.topic_mapping: Defines the mapping between GCP PubSub topics and MQTT topics. Must contain at least one item.
gcp_pubsub_consumer.pull_max_messages:
The maximum number of messages to retrieve from GCP PubSub in a single pull request.
 The actual number may be less than the specified value.
gcp_pubsub_consumer.connect_timeout: The timeout when connecting to the HTTP server.

hstreamdb.url: HStreamDB Server URL. Using gRPC http server address.
hstreamdb.record_template:
The HStream record template to be forwarded to the HStreamDB. Placeholders supported.
NOTE: When you use `raw record` template (which means the data is not a valid JSON), you should use `read` or `subscription` in HStream to get the data.

influxdb.server:
The IPv4 or IPv6 address or the hostname to connect to.

A host entry has the following form: `Host[:Port]`.

The InfluxDB default port 8086 is used if `[:Port]` is not specified.
influxdb.write_syntax:
Conf of InfluxDB line protocol to write data points. It is a text-based format that provides the measurement, tag set, field set, and timestamp of a data point, and placeholder supported. See also [InfluxDB 2.3 Line Protocol](https://docs.influxdata.com/influxdb/v2.3/reference/syntax/line-protocol/) and [InfluxDB 1.8 Line Protocol](https://docs.influxdata.com/influxdb/v1.8/write_protocols/line_protocol_tutorial/)
TLDR:
```[,=[,=]] =[,=] []```
Please note that a placeholder for an integer value must be annotated with a suffix `i`. For example `${'{'}payload.int_value{'}'}i`.

confluent_producer.connect_timeout: Maximum wait time for TCP connection establishment (including authentication time if enabled).
confluent_producer.bootstrap_hosts: A comma separated list of Kafka host[:port] endpoints to bootstrap the client. Default port number is 9092.
confluent_producer.min_metadata_refresh_interval: Minimum time interval the client has to wait before refreshing Kafka broker and topic metadata. Setting too small value may add extra load on Kafka.
confluent_producer.metadata_request_timeout: Maximum wait time when fetching metadata from Kafka.
confluent_producer.kafka_headers:
Please provide a placeholder to be used as Kafka Headers
e.g. ${'{'}pub_props{'}'}
Notice that the value of the placeholder must either be an object:
`{'{'}"foo": "bar"{'}'}`
confluent_producer.kafka_header_value_encode_mode:
Kafka headers value encode mode:
- `NONE`: only add binary values to Kafka headers;
- `JSON`: only add JSON values to Kafka headers, and encode it to JSON strings before sending.
confluent_producer.kafka_ext_headers:
Please provide more key-value pairs for Kafka headers.
The key-value pairs here will be combined with the value of `kafka_headers` field before sending to Kafka.
confluent_producer.key: Template to render Kafka message key. If the template is rendered into a NULL value (i.e. there is no such data field in Rule Engine context) then Kafka's NULL (but not empty string) is used.
confluent_producer.value: Template to render Kafka message value. If the template is rendered into a NULL value (i.e. there is no such data field in Rule Engine context) then Kafka's NULL (but not empty string) is used.
confluent_producer.partition_strategy:
Partition strategy is to tell the producer how to dispatch messages to Kafka partitions.
random: Randomly pick a partition for each message
key_dispatch: Hash Kafka message key to a partition number
confluent_producer.max_batch_bytes: Maximum bytes to collect in a Kafka message batch. Most of the Kafka brokers default to a limit of 1 MB batch size. EMQX's default value is less than 1 MB in order to compensate Kafka message encoding overheads (especially when each individual message is very small). When a single message is over the limit, it is still sent (as a single element batch).
confluent_producer.required_acks:
Required acknowledgements for Kafka partition leader to wait for its followers before it sends back the acknowledgement to EMQX Kafka producer
all_isr: Require all in-sync replicas to acknowledge.
leader_only: Require only the partition-leader's acknowledgement.
none: No need for Kafka to acknowledge at all.
confluent_producer.partition_count_refresh_interval:
The time interval for Kafka producer to discover increased number of partitions.
After the number of partitions is increased in Kafka, EMQX will start taking the
discovered partitions into account when dispatching messages per partition_strategy.
confluent_producer.max_inflight: Maximum number of batches allowed for Kafka producer (per-partition) to send before receiving acknowledgement from Kafka. Greater value typically means better throughput. However, there can be a risk of message reordering when this value is greater than 1.
confluent_producer.sync_query_timeout: This parameter defines the timeout limit for synchronous queries. It applies only when the bridge query mode is configured to 'sync'.
confluent_producer.mode:
Message buffer mode.
memory: Buffer all messages in memory. The messages will be lost in case of EMQX node restart
disk: Buffer all messages on disk. The messages on disk are able to survive EMQX node restart.
hybrid: Buffer message in memory first, when up to certain limit (see segment_bytes config for more information), then start offloading messages to disk, Like memory mode, the messages will be lost in case of EMQX node restart.
confluent_producer.per_partition_limit: Number of bytes allowed to buffer for each Kafka partition. When this limit is exceeded, old messages will be dropped in a trade for credits for new messages to be buffered.
confluent_producer.segment_bytes:
Applicable when buffer mode is set to disk or hybrid.
This value is to specify the size of each on-disk buffer file.
confluent_producer.memory_overload_protection:
Applicable when buffer mode is set to memory
EMQX will drop old buffered messages under high memory pressure. The high memory threshold is defined in config sysmon.os.sysmem_high_watermark. NOTE: This config only works on Linux.

kafka_producer.bootstrap_hosts: A comma separated list of Kafka host[:port] endpoints to bootstrap the client. Default port number is 9092.
kafka_producer.connect_timeout: Maximum wait time for TCP connection establishment (including authentication time if enabled).
kafka_producer.min_metadata_refresh_interval: Minimum time interval the client has to wait before refreshing Kafka broker and topic metadata. Setting too small value may add extra load on Kafka.
kafka_producer.metadata_request_timeout: Maximum wait time when fetching metadata from Kafka.
kafka_producer.kafka_headers:
Please provide a placeholder to be used as Kafka Headers
e.g. ${'{'}pub_props{'}'}
Notice that the value of the placeholder must either be an object:
`{'{'}"foo": "bar"{'}'}`
kafka_producer.kafka_header_value_encode_mode:
Kafka headers value encode mode:
- `NONE`: only add binary values to Kafka headers;
- `JSON`: only add JSON values to Kafka headers, and encode it to JSON strings before sending.
kafka_producer.kafka_ext_headers:
Please provide more key-value pairs for Kafka headers.
The key-value pairs here will be combined with the value of `kafka_headers` field before sending to Kafka.
kafka_producer.key: Template to render Kafka message key. If the template is rendered into a NULL value (i.e. there is no such data field in Rule Engine context) then Kafka's NULL (but not empty string) is used.
kafka_producer.value: Template to render Kafka message value. If the template is rendered into a NULL value (i.e. there is no such data field in Rule Engine context) then Kafka's NULL (but not empty string) is used.
kafka_producer.kafka_message_timestamp: Which timestamp to use. The timestamp is expected to be a millisecond precision Unix epoch which can be in string format, e.g. 1661326462115 or '1661326462115'. When the desired data field for this template is not found, or if the found data is not a valid integer, the current system timestamp will be used.
kafka_producer.partition_strategy:
Partition strategy is to tell the producer how to dispatch messages to Kafka partitions.
random: Randomly pick a partition for each message
key_dispatch: Hash Kafka message key to a partition number
kafka_producer.max_batch_bytes: Maximum bytes to collect in a Kafka message batch. Most of the Kafka brokers default to a limit of 1 MB batch size. EMQX's default value is less than 1 MB in order to compensate Kafka message encoding overheads (especially when each individual message is very small). When a single message is over the limit, it is still sent (as a single element batch).
kafka_producer.required_acks:
Required acknowledgements for Kafka partition leader to wait for its followers before it sends back the acknowledgement to EMQX Kafka producer
all_isr: Require all in-sync replicas to acknowledge.
leader_only: Require only the partition-leader's acknowledgement.
none: No need for Kafka to acknowledge at all.
kafka_producer.partition_count_refresh_interval:
The time interval for Kafka producer to discover increased number of partitions.
After the number of partitions is increased in Kafka, EMQX will start taking the
discovered partitions into account when dispatching messages per partition_strategy.
kafka_producer.max_inflight: Maximum number of batches allowed for Kafka producer (per-partition) to send before receiving acknowledgement from Kafka. Greater value typically means better throughput. However, there can be a risk of message reordering when this value is greater than 1.
kafka_producer.sync_query_timeout: This parameter defines the timeout limit for synchronous queries. It applies only when the bridge query mode is configured to 'sync'.
kafka_producer.mode:
Message buffer mode.
memory: Buffer all messages in memory. The messages will be lost in case of EMQX node restart
disk: Buffer all messages on disk. The messages on disk are able to survive EMQX node restart.
hybrid: Buffer message in memory first, when up to certain limit (see segment_bytes config for more information), then start offloading messages to disk, Like memory mode, the messages will be lost in case of EMQX node restart.
kafka_producer.per_partition_limit: Number of bytes allowed to buffer for each Kafka partition. When this limit is exceeded, old messages will be dropped in a trade for credits for new messages to be buffered.
kafka_producer.segment_bytes:
Applicable when buffer mode is set to disk or hybrid.
This value is to specify the size of each on-disk buffer file.
kafka_producer.memory_overload_protection:
Applicable when buffer mode is set to memory
EMQX will drop old buffered messages under high memory pressure. The high memory threshold is defined in config sysmon.os.sysmem_high_watermark. NOTE: This config only works on Linux.
kafka_producer.kafka_ext_header_key: Key of the Kafka header. Placeholders in the format of ${'{'}var{'}'} are supported.
kafka_producer.kerberos_principal: SASL GSSAPI authentication Kerberos principal. For example client_name{'@'}MY.KERBEROS.REALM.MYDOMAIN.COM, NOTE: The realm in use has to be configured in /etc/krb5.conf in EMQX nodes.
kafka_producer.kerberos_keytab_file: SASL GSSAPI authentication Kerberos keytab file path. NOTE: This file has to be placed in EMQX nodes, and the EMQX service runner user requires read permission.
kafka_producer.kafka_ext_header_value: Value of the Kafka header. Placeholders in the format of ${'{'}var{'}'} are supported.

kafka_consumer.bootstrap_hosts: A comma separated list of Kafka host[:port] endpoints to bootstrap the client. Default port number is 9092.
kafka_consumer.consumer_key_encoding_mode:
Defines how the key from the Kafka message is encoded before being forwarded via MQTT.
none Uses the key from the Kafka message unchanged. Note: in this case, the key must be a valid UTF-8 string.
base64 Uses base-64 encoding on the received key.
kafka_consumer.consumer_value_encoding_mode:
Defines how the value from the Kafka message is encoded before being forwarded via MQTT.
none Uses the value from the Kafka message unchanged. Note: in this case, the value must be a valid UTF-8 string.
base64 Uses base-64 encoding on the received value.
kafka_consumer.consumer_topic_mapping: Defines the mapping between Kafka topics and MQTT topics. Must contain at least one item.
kafka_consumer.consumer_offset_reset_policy: Defines from which offset a consumer should start fetching when there is no commit history or when the commit history becomes invalid.
kafka_consumer.consumer_mqtt_topic: Local topic to which consumed Kafka messages should be published to.
kafka_consumer.min_metadata_refresh_interval: Minimum time interval the client has to wait before refreshing Kafka broker and topic metadata. Setting too small value may add extra load on Kafka.
kafka_consumer.metadata_request_timeout: Maximum wait time when fetching metadata from Kafka.
kafka_consumer.connect_timeout: Maximum wait time for TCP connection establishment (including authentication time if enabled).
kafka_consumer.consumer_max_batch_bytes: Set how many bytes to pull from Kafka in each fetch request. Please note that if the configured value is smaller than the message size in Kafka, it may negatively impact the fetch performance.
kafka_consumer.consumer_offset_commit_interval_seconds: Defines the time interval between two offset commit requests sent for each consumer group.
kafka_consumer.mqtt_topic: MQTT topic or topic as data source (bridge input).  Should not configure this if the bridge is used as a rule action.
kafka_consumer.qos: MQTT QoS used to publish messages consumed from Kafka.
kafka_consumer.payload_template:
The template for transforming the incoming Kafka message. By default, it will use JSON format to serialize inputs from the Kafka message. Such fields are:
headers: an object containing string key-value pairs.
key: Kafka message key (uses the chosen key encoding).
offset: offset for the message.
topic: Kafka topic.
ts: message timestamp.
ts_type: message timestamp type, which is one of create, append or undefined.
value: Kafka message value (uses the chosen value encoding).

mongodb.collection: The collection where data will be stored into
mongodb.payload_template: The template for formatting the outgoing messages.  If undefined, rule engine will use JSON format to serialize all visible inputs, such as clientid, topic, payload etc.
mongodb.auth_source: Database name associated with the user's credentials.
mongodb.use_legacy_protocol: Whether to use MongoDB's legacy protocol for communicating with the database. The default is to attempt to automatically determine if the newer protocol is supported.
mongodb.max_overflow: The maximum number of additional workers that can be created when all workers in the pool are busy. This helps to manage temporary spikes in workload by allowing more concurrent connections to the MongoDB server.
mongodb.overflow_ttl: Period of time before workers that exceed the configured pool size ("overflow") to be terminated.
mongodb.overflow_check_period: Period for checking if there are more workers than configured ("overflow").
mongodb.local_threshold: The size of the latency window for selecting among multiple suitable MongoDB instances.
mongodb.connect_timeout: The duration to attempt a connection before timing out.
mongodb.socket_timeout: The duration to attempt to send or to receive on a socket before the attempt times out.
mongodb.server_selection_timeout: Specifies how long to block for server selection before throwing an exception.
mongodb.wait_queue_timeout: The maximum duration that a worker can wait for a connection to become available.
mongodb.heartbeat_frequency: Controls when the driver checks the state of the MongoDB deployment. Specify the interval between checks, counted from the end of the previous check until the beginning of the next one. If the number of connections is increased (which will happen, for example, if you increase the pool size), you may need to increase this period as well to avoid creating too many log entries in the MongoDB log file.
mongodb.min_heartbeat_frequency: Controls the minimum amount of time to wait between heartbeats.
mongodb.server:
The IPv4 or IPv6 address or the hostname to connect to.
A host entry has the following form: `Host[:Port]`.
The MongoDB default port 27017 is used if `[:Port]` is not specified.
mongodb.servers:
A Node list for Cluster to connect to. The nodes should be separated with commas, such as: `Node[,Node].`
For each Node should be: The IPv4 or IPv6 address or the hostname to connect to.
A host entry has the following form: `Host[:Port]`.
The MongoDB default port 27017 is used if `[:Port]` is not specified.

mysql.server:
The IPv4 or IPv6 address or the hostname to connect to.
A host entry has the following form: `Host[:Port]`.
The MySQL default port 3306 is used if `[:Port]` is not specified.

pgsql.server:
The IPv4 or IPv6 address or the hostname to connect to.
A host entry has the following form: `Host[:Port]`.
The default port 5432 is used if `[:Port]` is not specified.

redis.server:
The IPv4 or IPv6 address or the hostname to connect to.
A host entry has the following form: `Host[:Port]`.
The Redis default port 6379 is used if `[:Port]` is not specified.
redis.servers:
A Node list for Cluster to connect to. The nodes should be separated with commas, such as: `Node[,Node].`
For each Node should be: The IPv4 or IPv6 address or the hostname to connect to.
A host entry has the following form: `Host[:Port]`.
The Redis default port 6379 is used if `[:Port]` is not specified.
redis.sentinel: Sentinel mode. Must be set to 'sentinel' when Redis server is running in sentinel mode.
redis.command_template:
Redis command template used to export messages. Each list element stands for a command name or its argument.
For example, to push payloads in a Redis list by key `msgs`, the elements should be the following:
`rpush`, `msgs`, `${'{'}payload{'}'}`.

rocketmq.servers:
The IPv4 or IPv6 address or the hostname to connect to.
A host entry has the following form: `Host[:Port]`.
The RocketMQ default port 9876 is used if `[:Port]` is not specified.
rocketmq.send_buffer: The socket send buffer size of the RocketMQ driver client.
rocketmq.template:
Template, the default value is empty. When this value is empty the whole message will be stored in the RocketMQ.
The template can be any valid string with placeholders, example:
- ${'{'}id{'}'}, ${'{'}username{'}'}, ${'{'}clientid{'}'}, ${'{'}timestamp{'}'}
- {'{'}"id" : ${'{'}id{'}'}, "username" : ${'{'}username{'}'}{'}'}
rocketmq.sync_timeout: Timeout of RocketMQ driver synchronous call.

tdengine.server:
The IPv4 or IPv6 address or the hostname to connect to.
A host entry has the following form: `Host[:Port]`.
The TDengine default port 6041 is used if `[:Port]` is not specified.

sqlserver.server:
The IPv4 or IPv6 address or the hostname to connect to.
A host entry has the following form: `Host[:Port]`.
The SQL Server default port 1433 is used if `[:Port]` is not specified.

iotdb.base_url:
The base URL of the external IoTDB service's REST interface.
The URL has the following form `http://Host:Port`.
iotdb.iotdb_version: The version of the IoTDB system to connect to.
iotdb.enable_pipelining: A positive integer. Whether to send HTTP requests continuously, when set to 1, it means that after each HTTP request is sent, you need to wait for the server to return and then continue to send the next request.
iotdb.connect_timeout: The timeout when connecting to the HTTP server.
iotdb.timestamp: Supports the use of ${'{'}var{'}'} format as a placeholder, which should be in timestamp format. You can also use the following special characters to insert system time:</br>- `now`: Current millisecond-level timestamp</br>- `now_ms`: Current millisecond-level timestamp</br>- `now_us`: Current microsecond-level timestamp</br>- `now_ns`: Current nanosecond-level timestamp
iotdb.measurement: Supports the use of ${'{'}var{'}'} format as a placeholder.
iotdb.data_type: Data Type, supports the use of ${'{'}var{'}'} format as a placeholder.
iotdb.value: The value to be inserted, supports the use of ${'{'}var{'}'} format as a placeholder.
iotdb.device_id: A fixed device name this data should be inserted for. If empty it must either be set in the rule action, the message itself, or it will be extracted from the topic.

opents.timestamp: Second or millisecond level timestamp, supports placeholders in the format of ${'{'}var{'}'}.
opents.metric: The name of the metric, should be a unique identifier for the time series data, supports placeholders in the format of ${'{'}var{'}'}.
opents.tags: Tags for attaching metadata, each tag is a key-value pair, configured in the `key=value,key2=value2` format, and supports placeholders in the format of ${'{'}var{'}'}.
opents.value: The value of the data point, supports placeholders in the format of ${'{'}var{'}'}. It represents the actual measurement or observed value.

oracle.server:
The IPv4 or IPv6 address or the hostname to connect to.
A host entry has the following form: `Host[:Port]`.
The Oracle Database default port 1521 is used if `[:Port]` is not specified.
oracle.sql: SQL Template. The template string can contain placeholders for message metadata and payload field. The placeholders are inserted without any checking and special formatting, so it is important to ensure that the inserted values are formatted and escaped correctly.

rabbitmq.server: The RabbitMQ server address that you want to connect to (for example, localhost).
rabbitmq.port: The port number on which the RabbitMQ server is listening (default is 5672).
rabbitmq.exchange: The name of the RabbitMQ exchange where the messages will be sent.
rabbitmq.routing_key: The routing key used to route messages to the correct queue in the RabbitMQ exchange.
rabbitmq.virtual_host: The virtual host to use when connecting to the RabbitMQ server.
rabbitmq.heartbeat: The interval for sending heartbeat messages to the RabbitMQ server.
rabbitmq.delivery_mode: The delivery mode for messages published to RabbitMQ. Delivery mode `non_persistent` is suitable for messages that don't require persistence across RabbitMQ restarts, whereas delivery mode `persistent` is designed for messages that must survive RabbitMQ restarts.
rabbitmq.wait_for_publish_confirmations: A boolean value that indicates whether to wait for RabbitMQ to confirm message publication when using publisher confirms.
rabbitmq.publish_confirmation_timeout: The timeout for waiting for RabbitMQ to confirm message publication when using publisher confirms.
rabbitmq.timeout: The timeout for waiting on the connection to be established.
rabbitmq.payload_template: The template for formatting the payload of the message before sending it to RabbitMQ. Template placeholders, such as ${'{'}field1.sub_field{'}'}, will be substituted with the respective field's value. When left empty, the entire input message will be used as the payload, formatted as a JSON text. This behavior is equivalent to specifying ${'{'}.{'}'} as the payload template.

pulsar.servers: Specify the Pulsar Server URL in the format of scheme://host[:port] for the client to connect to. Multiple servers should be added as a comma-separated list. The supported schemes are pulsar:// (default) and pulsar+ssl://. The default port is 6650.
pulsar.strategy:
Choose how messages are dispatched to Pulsar partitions:
random: Messages are randomly assigned to partitions.
roundrobin: Messages are evenly distributed across available producers.
key_dispatch: Partitions to be selected are hashed and stored in the Pulsar message key of the first message in a batch.
pulsar.message_key: Template to render Pulsar message key.
pulsar.message_value: Template to render Pulsar message value.
pulsar.sync_timeout: Maximum wait time for receipt in synchronously publishing.
pulsar.retention_period: Specify the duration to buffer messages when disconnected from the Pulsar broker. Longer times increase memory/disk usage.
pulsar.send_buffer: Fine tune the socket send buffer. The default value is tuned for high throughput.
pulsar.max_batch_bytes: Specify the limit on the number of bytes collected in a batch. EMQX has set the default value to less than 5 MB to account for encoding overheads especially when handling small messages. If a single message exceeds the batch size limit, it will still be sent as a single-element batch, indicating it will be treated as a separate batch containing only that specific message.
pulsar.connect_timeout: Maximum wait time for TCP connection establishment (including authentication time if enabled).
pulsar.buffer_mode:
Message buffer mode:
memory: Buffer all messages in memory. The messages will be lost if EMQX node restarts.
disk: Buffer all messages on disk. The messages are designed to persist even during an EMQX node restart.
hybrid: Buffer message in memory first, when up to a certain limit (see segment_bytes config for more information), then start offloading messages to disk, the messages will be lost in if EMQX node restarts.
pulsar.buffer_per_partition_limit: Number of bytes allowed to buffer for each Pulsar partition. When the message limit is exceeded, older messages will be selectively dropped to allocate buffer space for new messages.
pulsar.buffer_segment_bytes:
Applicable when buffer mode is set to disk or hybrid.
This value is to specify the size of each on-disk buffer file.
pulsar.buffer_memory_overload_protection:
Applicable when buffer mode is set to memory
EMQX will drop old buffered messages under high memory pressure. The high memory threshold is defined in config sysmon.os.sysmem_high_watermark. NOTE: This config only works on Linux.

azure_event_hub_producer.bootstrap_hosts: A comma separated list of Azure Event Hubs Kafka host[:port] namespace endpoints to bootstrap the client. Default port number is 9093.
azure_event_hub_producer.connect_timeout: Maximum wait time for TCP connection establishment (including authentication time if enabled).
azure_event_hub_producer.min_metadata_refresh_interval: Minimum time interval the client has to wait before refreshing Azure Event Hubs Kafka broker and topic metadata. Setting too small value may add extra load on Azure Event Hubs.
azure_event_hub_producer.metadata_request_timeout: Maximum wait time when fetching metadata from Azure Event Hubs.
azure_event_hub_producer.connection_string: The Connection String for connecting to Azure Event Hubs. Should be the "connection string-primary key" of a Namespace shared access policy.
azure_event_hub_producer.max_batch_bytes: Maximum bytes to collect in an Azure Event Hubs message batch. Most of the Kafka brokers default to a limit of 1 MB batch size. EMQX's default value is less than 1 MB in order to compensate Kafka message encoding overheads (especially when each individual message is very small). When a single message is over the limit, it is still sent (as a single element batch).
azure_event_hub_producer.partition_strategy: Partition strategy is to tell the producer how to dispatch messages to Azure Event Hubs partitions. random: Randomly pick a partition for each message key_dispatch: Hash Azure Event Hubs message key to a partition number
azure_event_hub_producer.required_acks: Required acknowledgements for Azure Event Hubs partition leader to wait for its followers before it sends back the acknowledgement to EMQX Azure Event Hubs producer all_isr: Require all in-sync replicas to acknowledge. leader_only: Require only the partition-leader's acknowledgement.
azure_event_hub_producer.kafka_headers:
Please provide a placeholder to be used as Azure Event Hubs Headers
e.g. ${'{'}pub_props{'}'}
Notice that the value of the placeholder must either be an object: {'{'}\"foo\": \"bar\"{'}'}
azure_event_hub_producer.kafka_ext_headers:
Please provide more key-value pairs for Azure Event Hubs headers
The key-value pairs here will be combined with the value of kafka_headers field before sending to Azure Event Hubs.
azure_event_hub_producer.kafka_header_value_encode_mode:
Azure Event Hubs headers value encode mode
- NONE: only add binary values to Azure Event Hubs headers;
- JSON: only add JSON values to Azure Event Hubs headers, and encode it to JSON strings before sending.
azure_event_hub_producer.partition_count_refresh_interval: The time interval for Azure Event Hubs producer to discover increased number of partitions. After the number of partitions is increased in Azure Event Hubs, EMQX will start taking the discovered partitions into account when dispatching messages per partition_strategy.
azure_event_hub_producer.max_inflight: Maximum number of batches allowed for Azure Event Hubs producer (per-partition) to send before receiving acknowledgement from Azure Event Hubs. Greater value typically means better throughput. However, there can be a risk of message reordering when this value is greater than 1.
azure_event_hub_producer.sync_query_timeout: This parameter defines the timeout limit for synchronous queries. It applies only when the bridge query mode is configured to 'sync'.
azure_event_hub_producer.key: Template to render Azure Event Hubs message key. If the template is rendered into a NULL value (i.e. there is no such data field in Rule Engine context) then Azure Event Hubs's NULL (but not empty string) is used.
azure_event_hub_producer.value: Template to render Azure Event Hubs message value. If the template is rendered into a NULL value (i.e. there is no such data field in Rule Engine context) then Azure Event Hubs's NULL (but not empty string) is used.
azure_event_hub_producer.kafka_ext_header_key: Key of the Azure Event Hubs header. Placeholders in format of ${'{'}var{'}'} are supported.
azure_event_hub_producer.kafka_ext_header_value: Value of the Azure Event Hubs header. Placeholders in format of ${'{'}var{'}'} are supported.
azure_event_hub_producer.mode: Message buffer mode. memory: Buffer all messages in memory. The messages will be lost in case of EMQX node restart disk: Buffer all messages on disk. The messages on disk are able to survive EMQX node restart. hybrid: Buffer message in memory first, when up to certain limit (see segment_bytes config for more information), then start offloading messages to disk, Like memory mode, the messages will be lost in case of EMQX node restart.
azure_event_hub_producer.per_partition_limit: Number of bytes allowed to buffer for each Azure Event Hubs partition. When this limit is exceeded, old messages will be dropped in a trade for credits for new messages to be buffered.
azure_event_hub_producer.segment_bytes: Applicable when buffer mode is set to disk or hybrid. This value is to specify the size of each on-disk buffer file.
azure_event_hub_producer.memory_overload_protection: Applicable when buffer mode is set to memory EMQX will drop old buffered messages under high memory pressure. The high memory threshold is defined in config sysmon.os.sysmem_high_watermark. NOTE: This config only works on Linux.

kinesis.payload_template: The template for formatting the outgoing messages.  If undefined, will send all the available context in JSON format.
kinesis.aws_access_key_id: Access Key ID for connecting to Amazon Kinesis.
kinesis.aws_secret_access_key: AWS Secret Access Key for connecting to Amazon Kinesis.
kinesis.endpoint: The url of Amazon Kinesis endpoint.
kinesis.stream_name: The Amazon Kinesis Stream to publish messages to.
kinesis.partition_key: The Amazon Kinesis Partition Key associated to published message. Placeholders in format of ${'{'}var{'}'} are supported.

greptimedb.server: The IPv4 or IPv6 address or the hostname to connect to. A host entry has the following form: `Host[:Port]`.
greptimedb.write_syntax:
Conf of GreptimeDB gRPC protocol to write data points. Write syntax is a text-based format that provides the measurement, tag set, field set, and timestamp of a data point, and placeholder supported, which is the same as InfluxDB line protocol.
See also [InfluxDB 2.3 Line Protocol](https://docs.influxdata.com/influxdb/v2.3/reference/syntax/line-protocol/) and
[InfluxDB 1.8 Line Protocol](https://docs.influxdata.com/influxdb/v1.8/write_protocols/line_protocol_tutorial/) </br>
TLDR:</br>
```
<measurement>[,<tag_key>=<tag_value>[,<tag_key>=<tag_value>]] <field_key>=<field_value>[,<field_key>=<field_value>] [<timestamp>]
```
Please note that a placeholder for an integer value must be annotated with a suffix `i`. For example `${'{'}payload.int_value{'}'}i`.

syskeeper_proxy.listen: The listening address for this Syskeeper proxy server
syskeeper_proxy.handshake_timeout: The maximum to wait for the handshake when a connection is created

syskeeper_forwarder.server: The address of the Syskeeper proxy server
syskeeper_forwarder.ack_mode:
Specify whether the proxy server should reply with an acknowledgement for the message forwarding, can be:
- need_ack
- no_ack
syskeeper_forwarder.ack_timeout: The maximum time to wait for an acknowledgement from the proxy server
syskeeper_forwarder.target_topic: The topic for the forwarded message
syskeeper_forwarder.target_qos: The QoS for the forwarded message, left blank for the original topic

elasticsearch.server: The REST server address of the ElasticSearch service.
elasticsearch.routing: Specifies the shard in the index where the document should be stored. If left blank, Elasticsearch decides.
elasticsearch.wait_for_active_shards:
Number of shard replicas that must be active before proceeding.
Set to "all" or any positive integer, up to the total number of shards in the index (number_of_replicas+1).
Default: 1, i.e., the primary shard.
elasticsearch.index: Name of the index or index alias to perform the operation on, supports ${'{'}var{'}'} format placeholders.
elasticsearch.id: Unique identifier for the document within the index, supports ${'{'}var{'}'} format placeholders. If ID is not specified, it is autogenerated by Elasticsearch.
elasticsearch.doc:
Custom document template, supports ${'{'}var{'}'} format placeholders, must be convertible to a JSON object.
For example, `{'{'} "field": "${'{'}payload.field{'}'}" {'}'}`, or `${'{'}payload{'}'}`.
elasticsearch.overwrite: Overwrites the document if it already exists, otherwise the write will fail.
elasticsearch.enable_pipelining: A positive integer. Whether to send HTTP requests continuously, when set to 1, it means that after each HTTP request is sent, you need to wait for the server to return and then continue to send the next request.
elasticsearch.connect_timeout: The timeout when connecting to the HTTP server.
elasticsearch.doc_as_upsert: Treat the update operation as an insert operation when the document to be updated does not exist, and insert the provided document as a new document.
